block.p: The White House called for patience. Administration officials appealed to Congress and the public to stand firm during an expected long standoff with President Saddam Hussein of Iraq.
U.S. and Israel say they'll seek ''credible'' peace process
The White House called for patience. Administration officials appealed to Congress and the public to stand firm during an expected long standoff with President Saddam Hussein of Iraq.
U.S. and Israel say they'll seek ''credible'' peace process
Tokyo and Moscow issue joint appeal on Persian Gulf crisis
Thatcher prepares for costly and patient struggle
East Europeans agree to sell gas masks to Saudi civilians
Crisis breathes life into a moribund U.N. panel
A set of conservative columnists has turned away from fighting liberalism and started battling one another over America's intervention in the Middle East.
In Baghdad's bazaars, fear is in good supply
Hussein says sanctions are depriving Iraqi children of milk
Tunis bristles with hostility to U.S. gulf moves

Anti-Semitism in Eastern Europe needs to be attacked on a major scale, Vatican officials and Jewish and Roman Catholic leaders from 16 nations said. Their statement followed a four-day meeting in Prague.

A resort town in West Germany turns into a shrine each summer as hundreds of thousands of people come to admire the most popular hero a German writer has ever produced: a wise Apache chief named Winnetou.
Rights observers reportedly ousted in Yugoslavia

The opponents of Benazir Bhutto, the former Prime Minister of Pakistan who was abruptly dismissed last month, seem willing to go to any lengths to discredit her so that she cannot be re-elected, politicians, diplomats and ordinary voters say.
Seoul rejects North's plan to end hostilities
U.S. to open talks with Cambodian Communists
De Klerk moves to reassure whites on a new constitution
Slavery helps build a boomtown in Amazon
Mexico City Journal: A muted hurrah for Columbus

Many Americans infected with AIDS have not been receiving potentially life-prolonging drugs that were recommended by Federal authorities a year ago, medical experts say, because they have not been tested and do not know they are infected.

The Federal Medicare program is being squeezed as never before, and patients and doctors are both complaining. Some experts say Americans will have to put up more money or expect reductions in coverage, else the program become insolvent.
Higher risk is found among children of smokers

Americans are ignorant about sex, according to a new survey. The Kinsey Institute and the Roper Organization asked 1,974 adult Americans 18 questions about their basic knowledge of sex and reproduction.

Detroit has lost half its population since 1950, Federal officials say. What is worrying Detroit the most, though, is the prospect that it may become the first city ever to drop below 1 million in the census count.

The countdown for the space shuttle was abruptly halted because of a fuel leak and the launching of Columbia was postponed for a third time. The shuttle fleet has been plagued by such leaks for three months.

The drug war remains a top priority despite events in the Persian Gulf, President Bush vowed. His statement came even as Congressional critics charged that the Administration's drug policy had largely ignored the nation's drug-ravaged cities.
Washington Talk: Drug war underlines fickleness of public
Negotiators prepare for a last-ditch effort to cut the deficit
For deficit talks site, the price is right
Dukakis orders further cuts as state tax collections fall
Senator's widow loses suit against government doctors
Three radicals agree to plead guilty in bombing case
Arctic ozone levels are lower than expected

The family of the young Utah tourist who was fatally stabbed in the New York subway Sunday were so fond of the city, friends and neighbors say, that they could well have appeared in an ''I love New York'' ad campaign.
Gangs that dance to a violent beat
No end to rising subway crime, chief asserts
Violence will now find Dinkins showing outrage

New York City's Schools Chancellor, Joseph A. Fernandez, is considering seeking legislation that would put the entire custodial work force directly under the control of the New York City Board of Education.

Public schools in Tarrytown, N.Y., opened under the constraints of an austerity budget. The budget was imposed by the Board of Education after tax-weary voters twice rejected a proposed school budget.
Schools in New Jersey open amid uncertainty
A yacht club at the edge of the Bronx with a ''million-dollar view'' of the Manhattan skyline has survived for nearly a century as the neighborhood around it has changed.
Rinfret proposes cutting spending and taxes to bridge gaps
Three cases voided in sex incident near St. John's
First witness is heard in case of burned boy

Keeping house in the grand manner

With advent of new heart drugs, delay in seeking help is killer

Mark M. Lowenthal: As Helsinki nears, Gorbachev fades
